candidate_text: In that most singular and venerable thoroughfare, yclept Piccadilly, there dwelt an individual of curious disposition and manifold talents, known to his acquaintance as Mr. Edwin Fothergill.
It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a person beset by idleness and indolence shall be prone to distraction and flightiness.

The Indolent Gentleman and the Fleeting Nature of Leisure

It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a man in possession of a modest fortune must be in want of some gentle amusement to while away his hours.
My dear friend, permit me to regale you with the tale of Mr. Timothy Wimpleton, a gentleman whose peculiarity of character renders him at once both intriguing and infuriating.

Pray tell, dear fellow," I said to him, "what felicitous event hath wrought such a transformation?"
"I have just received tidings," he replied, his eyes aglow with merriment, "that my cousin, the benevolent Mrs. Wilkins, hath seen fit to bestow upon me a modest estate in the countryside."
"A bounty most fortuitous indeed!"
"Verily," I exclaimed, "this is news most excellent!
I congratulated him warmly, exhorting him to indulge freely in this unexpected windfall, even as a wise and prudent man must temper his indulgences with prudence and circumspection.

I congratulated him heartily, for it is ever thus, that Providence doth reward those whose virtue and probity warrant her approbation.
